All fooles. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1605. Date first performed: 1601.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Rynaldo Fortunio Valerio Gostanzo Marc Antonio Gazetta Bellanora Cornelio Gratiana Dariotto Claudio Pock Notary Drawer Page. Prologue/Epilogue Omnes

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.l: The fortune of a Stage (like Fortunes self)
Amazeth greatest judgments: And none knows
The hidden causes of those strange effects,
That rise from this Hell, or fall from this Heaven:
Who can show cause, why your wits, that in aim
At higher Objects, scorn to compose Plays;
(Though we are sure they could, would they vouchsafe it?)
Should (without means to make) judge better far,
Than those that make, and yet ye see they can;
For without your applause, wretched is he
That undertakes the Stage, and he is more blessed,
That with your glorious favours can contest.
Who can show cause, why the ancient Comic vain
Of Eupolis and Cratinus (now reuin'd,
Subject to personal application)
Should be exploded by some bitter spleens?
Yet merely Comical, and harmless jests
(Though never so witty) be esteemed but joys,
If void of the other satyrismes sauce?
Who can show cause why quick Venerian jests,
Should sometimes ravish? sometimes fall far short,
Of the just length and pleasure of your ears?
When our pure Dames,think them much less obscene,
Than those that win your Panegyric spleen?
But our poor dooms (alas) you know are nothing;
To your inspired censure, ever we
Must needs submit, and there is the mystery.
Great are the gifts given to united heads,
To gifts, attire, to fair attire, the stage
Helps much, for if our other audience see
You on the stage depart before we end,
Our wits go with you all, and we are fools;
So Fortune governs in these stage events,
That merit bears least sway in most contents.
How we shall then appear, we must refer
To Magic of your dooms, that never err.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Can one self cause, in subjects so alike
As you two are, produce effect so unlike?
One like the Turtle, all in mournful strains,
Wailing his fortunes? The other like the Lark
Mounting the sky in shrill and cheerful notes,
Chanting his joys aspired, and both for love:
In one, love raiseth by his violent heat,
Moist vapours from the heart into the eyes,
From whence they drown his breast in daily showers;
In the other, his divided power infuseth
Only a temperate and most kindly warmth,
That gives life to those fruits of wit and virtue,
Which the unkind hand of an uncivil father,
Had almost nipped in the delightsome blossom.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: O brother love rewards our services
With a most partial and injurious hand,
If you consider well our different fortunes:
Valerio loves, and joys the dame he loves:
I love, and never can enjoy the sight
Of her I love, so far from conquering
In my desires assault, that I can come
To lay no battery to the Fort I seek;
All passages to it, so strongly kept,
By straight guard of her Father.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: I dare swear,
If just desert in love measured reward,
Your fortune should exceed Valerios far:
For I am witness (being your Bedfellow)
Both to the daily and the nightly service,
You do unto the deity of love,
In vows, sighs, tears, and solitary watches,
He never serves him with such sacrifice,
Yet hath his Bow and shafts at his command:
Loves service is much like our humorous Lords;
Where Minions carry more than Servitors,
The bold and careless servant still obtains:
The modest and respective, nothing gains;
You never see your love, unless in dreams,
He, Hymen puts in whole possession:
What different stars reigned when your loves were borne,
He forced to wear the Willow, you the home?
But brother, are you not ashamed to make
yourself a slave to the base Lord of love,
Begot of Fancy, and of Beauty borne?
And what is Beauty? a mere Quintessence,
Whose life is not in being, but in seeming;
And therefore is not to all eyes the same,
But like a cozening picture, which one way
Shows like a Crow, another like a Swan:
And upon what ground is this Beauty drawn?
Upon a Woman, a most brittle creature,
And would to God (for my part) that were all.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: But tell me brother, did you never love?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: You know I did, and was beloved again,
And that of such a Dame, as all men deemed
Honoured, and made me happy in her favours,
Exceeding fair she was not; and yet fair
In that she never studied to be fairer
Than Nature made her; Beauty cost her nothing,
Her virtues were so rare, they would have made
An AEthyop beautiful: At least, so thought
By such as stood aloof, and did observe her
With credulous eyes: But what they were indeed
I will spare to blaze, because I loved her once,
Only I found her such, as for her sake
I vow eternal wars against their whole sex,
Inconstant shuttlecocks, loving fools, and jesters;
Men rich in dirt, and titles sooner won
With the most vile, than the most virtuous:
Found true to none: if one amongst whole hundreds
Chance to be chaste, she is so proud withal,
Wayward and rude, that one of unchaste life,
Is oftentimes approved, a worthier wife:
Undressed, sluttish, nasty, to their husbands,
Spunged up, adorned, and painted to their lovers:
All day in ceaseless uproar with their households,
If all the night their husbands have not pleased them,
Like hounds, most kind, being beaten and abused,
Like wolves, most cruel, being kindliest used.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Fie, thou profanest the deity of their sex.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: Brother I read, that AEgipt heretofore,
Had Temples of the riches frame on earth;
Much like this goodly edifice of women,
With Alabaster pillars were those Temples,
Upheld and beautified, and so are women:
Most curiously glazed, and so are women;
Cunningly painted too, and so are women;
In outside wondrous heavenly, so are women:
But when a stranger viewed those fanes within,
Instead of Gods and Goddesses, he should find
A painted fowl, a fury, or a serpent,
And such celestial inner parts have women.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Rynaldo, the poor Fox that lost his tail,
Persuaded others also to lose theirs:
Thyself, for one perhaps that for desert
Or some defect in thy attempts refused thee,
Revilest the whole sex, beauty, love and all:
I tell thee,Love, is Natures second son ,
Causing a spring of virtues where he shines,
And as without the Sun, the Worlds great eye,
All colours, beauties, both of Art and Nature,
Are given in vain to men, so without love
All beauties bred in women are in vain;
All virtues borne in men lie buried,
For love informs them as the Sun doth colours,
And as the Sun reflecting his warm beams
Against the earth, begets all fruits and flowers:
So love, fair shining in the inward man,
Brings forth in him the honourable fruits
Of valour, wit, virtue, and haughty thoughts,
Brave resolution, and divine discourse:
O it is the Paradise, the heaven of earth,
And didst thou know the comfort of two hearts,
In one delicious harmony united?
As to joy one joy, and think both one thought,
Live both one life, and therein double life:
To see their souls met at an enter-view
In their bright eyes, at parley in their lips,
Their language kisses: And to observe the rest,
Touches, embraces, and each circumstance
Of all loves most unmatched ceremonies:
Thou wouldst abhor thy tongue for blasphemy,
O who can comprehend how sweet love tastes,
But he that hath been present at his feasts?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Are you in that vain too Valerio?
It were fitter you should be about your charge,
How Plough and Cart goes forward : I have known
Your joys were all employed in husbandry,
Your study was how many loads of hay
A meadow of so many acres yielded;
How many Oxen such a close would sat?
And is your rural service now converted
From Pan to Cupid? and from beasts to women?
O if your father knew this, what a lecture
Of bitter castigation he would read you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My father? why my father? does he think
To rob me of myself? I hope I know
I am a Gentleman, though his covetous humour
And education hath transformed me Bayly,
And made me overseer of his pastures,
I will be myself, in spite of husbandry.
And see bright heaven here comes my husbandry,
Here shall my cattle graze, here Nectar drink,
Here will I hedge and ditch, here hide my treasure,
O poor Fortunio, how wouldst thou triumph,
If thou enjoyedest this happiness with my Sister?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I were in heaven if once it were come to that.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: And methinks it is my heaven that I am past it,
And should the wretched Machiavellian,
The covetous knight your father see this sight
Lusty Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'sfoot Sir if he should,
He shall perceive ere long my skill extends
To something more, than sweaty husbandry.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: I will bear thee witness, thou canst skill of dice,
Cards, tennis, wenching, dancing, and what not?
And this is something more than husbandry:
Thou art known in Ordinaries, and Tobacco shops,
Trusted in Taverns and in vaulting houses,
And this is something more than husbandry:
Yet all this while, thy father apprehends thee
For the most tame and thrifty Groom in Europe.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Well, he hath ventured on a marriage
Would quite undo him, did his father know it.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Know it? alas Sir where can he bestow
This poor Gentlewoman he hath made his wife,
But his inquisitive father will hear of it?
Who, like the dragon to the esperean fruit,
Is to his haunts? slight hence, the old knight comes.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Rynaldo.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: Who is that calls? what Sir Gostanzo?
How fares your Knighthood Sir?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Say who was that
Shrunk at my entry here? was it not your brother?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: He shrunk not sir, his business called him hence.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: And was it not my son that went out with him?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: I saw not him, I was in serious speech
About a secret business with my brother.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Sure it was my son, what made he here? I sent him
About affairs to be dispatched in haste .

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Well sir, lest silence breed unjust suspect,
I will tell a secret I am sworn to keep,
And crave your honoured assistance in it.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What is it Rynaldo?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: This sir, it was your son.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: And what young gentlewoman gracest their company?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Thereon depends the secret I must utter:
That gentlewoman hath my brother married.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Married? what is she?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Faith sir, a gentlewoman:
But her unusuring dowry must be told
Out of her beauty.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Is it true Rynaldo?
And does your father understand so much?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: That was the motion sir, I was entreating
Your son to make to him, because I know
He is well spoken, and may much prevail
In satisfying my father, who much loves him,
Both for his wisdom and his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Indeed he is one can tell his tale I tell you,
And for his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: O sir, had you heard,
What thrifty discipline he gave my brother,
For making choice without my fathers knowledge,
And without riches, you would have admired him.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I know him well, but what was it?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: That in the choice of wives men must respect
The chief wife, riches, that in every course
A man's chief Lodestar should shine out of riches,
Love nothing heartily in this world but riches;
Cast off all friends, all studies, all delights,
All honesty, and religion for riches:
And many such, which wisdom sure he learned
Of his experient father; yet my brother,
So soothes his rash affection, and presumes
So highly on my fathers gentle nature,
That he is resolved to bring her home to him,
And like enough he will.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: And like enough.
Your silly father too, will put it up,
An honest knight, but much too much indulgent
To his presuming children.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: What a difference
Doth interpose itself, twixt him and you?
Had your son used you thus?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: My son? alas
I hope to bring him up in other fashion,
Follows my husbandry, sets early foot
Into the world; he comes not at the city,
Nor knows the city Arts.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: But dice and wenching.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Acquaints himself with no delight but getting,
A perfect pattern of sobriety,
Temperance and husbandry to all my household,
And what is his company I pray? not wenches.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Wenches? I durst besworn he never smelt a wenches breath
Yet, but me thinks it were fit you sought him out a wife.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: A wife Rynaldo?
He dares not look a woman in the face.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: 'sfoot hold him to one, your son such a sheep?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: It is strange in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Well sir, though for my thriftless brothers sake,
I little care how my wronged father takes it,
Yet for my fathers quiet, if yourself
Would join hands with your wife and toward Son,
I should deserve it some way.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Good Rynaldo.
I love you and your father, but this matter
Is not for me to deal in: And it is needless,
You say your brother is resolved, presuming
Your father will allow it.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: See my father, since you are resolute not to move him Sir,
In any case conceal the secret
By way of an atonement let me pray you will.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Upon mine honour.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: God save thee honourable Knight Gostanzo.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Friend Marc Antonio? welcome, and I think
I have good news to welcome you withal.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: He cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What news I pray you Sir?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: You have a forward, valiant eldest Son,
But wherein is his forwardness, and valour?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not wherein you intend him so.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Forward before, valiant behind, his duty,
That he hath dared before your due consent
To take a wife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A wife sir? what is she?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: One that is rich enough, her hair pure Amber,
Her forehead mother of pearl, her fair eyes
Two wealthy diamonds: her lips, mines of Rubies:
Her teeth, are orient pearl; her neck, pure Ivory.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Jest not good Sir, in an affair so serious,
I love my son, and if his youth reward me
With his contempt of my consent in marriage:
It is to be feared that his presumption builds not
Of his good choice, that will bear out itself ,
And being bad, the news is worse than bad.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What call you bad? is it bad to be poor?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The world accounts it so; but if my son
Have in her birth and virtues held his choice,
Without disparagement, the fault is less.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Sits the wind there blows there so calm a gale
From a contemned and deserved anger?
Are you so easy to be disobeyed?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What should I do? if my enamoured son
Have been so forward; I assure myself
He did it more to satisfy his love,
Than to incense my hate, or to neglect me.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: A passing kind construction; suffer this,
You ope him doors to any villainy,
He will dare to sell, to pawn, run ever riot,
Despise your love in all, and laugh at you:
And that knights competency you have gotten
With care and labour; he with lust and idleness
Will bring into the stipend of a beggar;
All to maintain a wanton whirligig,
Worth nothing more than she brings on her back,
Yet all your wealth too little for that back:
By heaven I pity your declining state,
For be assured your son hath set his foot,
In the right pathway to consumption:
Up to the heart in love ; and for that love,
Nothing can be too dear his love desires:
And how insatiate and unlimited,
Is the ambition and the beggarly pride
Of a dame hoised from a beggars state,
To a state competent and plentiful,
You cannot be so simple not to know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I must confess the mischief: But alas
Where is in me the power of remedy?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Where? in your just displeasure: cast him off,
Receive him not, let him endure the use
Of their enforced kindness that must trust him
For meat and money, for apparel, house,
And everything belongs to that estate,
Which he must learn with want of misery,
Since pleasure and a full estate hath blinded
His dissolute desires.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What should I do?
If I should banish him my house and sight,
What desperate resolution might it breed?
To run into the wars, and there to live
In want of competency and perhaps
Taste the unrecoverable loss of his chief limbs,
Which while he hath in peace, at home with me,
May with his spirit, ransom his estate
From any loss his marriage can procure.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Is it true? Ne let him run into the war,
And lose what limbs he can: better one branch
Be lopped away, than all the whole tree should perish:
And for his wants, better young want than old,
You have a younger son at Padoa,
I like his learning well, make him your heir,
And let your other walk: let him buy wit
At his own charge, not at his fathers, if you lose him,
You lose no more than that was lost before,
If you recover him, you find a son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I cannot part with him.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: If it be so, and that your love to him be so extreme,
In needful dangers, ever choose the least:
If he should be in mind to pass the Seas,
Your son Rynaldo (who told me all this)
Will tell me that, and so we shall prevent it:
If by no stern course you will venture that,
Let him come home to me with his fair wife:
And if you chance to see him, shake him up,
As if your wrath were hard to be reflected,
That he may fear hereafter to offend
In other dissolute courses: At my house
With my advice and my sons good example,
Who shall serve as a glass for him to see
His faults, and mend them to his president:
I make no doubt but of a dissolute Son
And disobedient, to send him home
Both dutiful and thrifty,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Gostanzo!
Could you do this, you should preserve yourself,
A perfect friend of me, and me a Son.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Remember you your part, and fear not mine:
Rate him, revile him, and renounce him too:
Speak, can you do it man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will do all I can.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Alas good man, how Nature overweighs him.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: God save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Rynaldo, All the News
You told me as a secret, I perceive
Is passing common;, for your Father knows it,
The first thing he related, was the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: And was extremely moved?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Beyond all measure:
But I did all I could to quench his fury:
Told him how easy it was for a young man
To run that Amorous course: and though his choice
Were nothing rich, yet she was gently borne,
Well qualified and beautiful: But he still
Was quite relentless, and would needs renounce him.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: My Brother knows it well, and is resolved
To trail a Pike in Field, rather than bide
The more feared push of my vexed Fathers fury.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Indeed that is one way: but are no more means
Left to his fine wits, than to incense his Father
With a more violent rage, and to redeem
A great offence with greater?

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: So I told him:
But to a desperate mind all breath is lost,

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Go to, let him be wise, and use his friends,
Amongst whom, I will be foremost to his Father:
Without this desperate error he intends
Joined to the other; I will not doubt to make him
Easy return into his Fathers favour:
So he submit himself, as duty binds him:
For Fathers will be known to be themselves,
And often when their angers are not deep,
Will paint an outward Rage upon their looks.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: All this I told him Sir; but what says he ?
I know my Father will not be reclaimed,
He will think that if he wink at this offence,
It will open doors to any villainy:
I will dare to sell to pawn, and run all riot,
To laugh at all his patience, and consume
All he hath purchased to an honoured purpose,
In maintenance of a wanton Whirligig,
Worth nothing more than she wears on her back.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: The very words I used to incense his Father,
But good Rinoldo let him be advised:
How would his Father grieve, should he be maimed,
Or quite miscarry in the ruthless war?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I told him so; but better far (said he)
One branch should utterly be lopped away,
Than the whole Tree of all his race should perish:
And for his wants, better young want, than old.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: By heaven the same words still I used to his Father.
Why comes this about? Well, good Rinaldo,
If he dare not endure his Fathers looks ,
Let him and his fair wife come home to me,
Till I have qualified his Fathers passion,
He shall be kindly welcome, and be sure
Of all the intercession I can use.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I thank you sir, I will try what I can do,
Although I fear me I shall strive in vain.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Well, try him, try him.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Thanks sir, so I will.
See, this old politic dissembling Knight,
Now he perceives my Father so affectionate,
And that my brother may hereafter live
By him and his, with equal use of either,
He will put on a face of hollow friendship.
But this will prove an excellent ground to sow
The seed of mirth amongst us. I will go seek
Valerio and my brother, and tell them
Such news of their affairs, as they will admire.

sp.speaker: Gaze.
sp.l: How happy are your fortunes above mine?
Both still being wood and court: still so feeding
On the delights of love, that still you find
An appetite to more; where I am cloyed,
And being bound to love sports, care not for them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That is your fault Gazetta, we have Loves
And wish continual company with them
In honoured marriage rites, which you enjoy.
But seld or never can we get a look
Of those we love, Fortunio my dear choice
Dare not be known to love me, nor come near
My Fathers house, where I as in a prison
Consume my lost days, and the tedious nights,
My Father guarding me for one I hate
And Gratiana here my brothers love,
Joys him by so much stealth, that vehement fear
Drinks up the sweetness of their stolen delights
Where you enjoy a husband, and may freely
Perform all obsequies you desire to love.

sp.speaker: Gaze.
sp.l: Indeed I have a husband, and his love
Is more than I desire, being vainly jealous:
Extremes, though contrary,have the like effects,
Extremes heat mortifies like extreme cold:
Extreme love breeds society as well
As extreme Hatred: and too violent rigour,
Tempts Chastity as much, as too much Licence:
There is no man's eye fixed on me but doth pierce
My Husbands soul: If any sake my welfare?
He straight doubts Treason practised to his bed:
Fancies but to himself all likelihoods
Of my wrong to him, and says all on me
For certain truths; yet seeks he with his best,
To put Disguise on all his Jealousy,
Fearing perhaps, lest it may teach me that,
Which otherwise I should not dream upon :
Yet lives he still abroad, at great expense,
Turns merely Gallant from his Farmers state,
Uses all Games and recreations:
Runs Races with the Gallants of the Court,
Feasts them at home, and entertains them costly,
And then upbraids me with their company:
See see, we shall be troubled with him now.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Now Ladies, what plots have we now in hand?
They say, when only one Dame is alone,
She plots some mischief; but if three together,
They plot three hundred: Wife, the Air is sharpe,
You had best to take the house lest you take cold.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Alas this time of year yields no such danger,

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Go, in I say; a friend of yours attends you.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: He is of your bringing, and may stay.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay stand not chopping Logic; in I pray.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Ye see, Gentle women, what my happiness is,
These humours reign in marriage; humours, humours.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Now by my Sooth I am no fortune teller,
And would be loath to prove so; yet pronounce
This at adventure, that it were indecorum
This Heifer should want horns.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Fie on this Love,
I rather wish to want, than purchase so.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.l: Indeed such Love is like a Smoky fire
In a cold morning; though the Fire be cheerful,
Yet is the Smoke so sour and cumbersome,
It were better lose the Fire, than find the Smoke:
Such an attendant then as Smoke to Fire,
Is Jealousy to Love: Better want both.
Than have both.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Come Fortunio, now take hold
On this occasion, as myself on this:
One couple more would make a Barley-break.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I fear Valerio, we shall break too soon,
Your Fathers Jealousy Spy-all, will displease us .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well Wench, the day will come his Argus eyes
Will shut, and thou shalt open: 'sfoot, I think
Dame Natures memory begins to fail her:
If I write but my Name in Mercers Books,
I am as sure to have at six months end
A Rascal at my elbow with his Mace,
As I am sure my Fathers not far hence:
My Father yet hath ought Dame Nature debt
These threescore years and ten, yet calls not on him:
But if she turn her Debt book over once,
And finding him her debtor, do but send
Her Sergeant Iohn Death to arrest his body,
Our Souls shall rest Wench then, And the free Light
Shall triumph in our faces; where now Night,
In imitation of my Fathers frowns,
Lours at our meeting:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: See where the Scholar comes.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Down on your knees; poor lovers reverence learning

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I pray thee why Rinaldo?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Mark what cause
Flows from my depth of knowledge to your loves,
To make you kneel and bless me while you live.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: I pray thee good Scholars give us cause.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Mark then, erect your ears: you know what horror
Would fly on your love from your fathers frowns,
If he should know it. And your sister here,
(My brothers sweet heart) knows as well what rage
Would seize his powers for her, if he should know
My brother wooed her, or that she loved him,
Is not this true? speak all.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: All this is true.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: It is as true that now you meet by stealth
In depth of midnight, kissing out at grates,
Clime over walls. And all this I will reform.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: By Logic.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Well sir, you shall have all means
To live in one house, eat and drink together,
Meet and kiss your fills.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: All this by learning?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Aye , and your frowning father know all this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Aye marry, small learning may prove that.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Nay he shall know it, and desire it too,
Welcome my Brother to him, and your wife,
Entreating both to come and dwell with him.
Is not this strange?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Aye too strange to be true.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: It is in this head shall work it: Therefore hear;
Brother this Lady you must call your wife,
For I have told her sweet hearts Father here
That she is your wife; and because my Father
(Who now believes it) must be quieted
Before you see him, you must live a while
As husband to her, in his Fathers house,
Ualeria here is a simple mean for you
To lie at rack and manger with your wedlock
And brother, for yourself to meet as freely.
With this your long desired and barred love.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: You make us wonder.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Peace, be ruled by me,
And you shall see to what a perfect shape
He bring this rude Plot, which blind Chance (the Ape
Of Counsel and advice) hath brought forth blind,
Ualerio, can your heat of love forbear
Before your Father, and allow my Brother
To use some kindness to your wife before him?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Aye before him, I do not greatly care,
Nor any where indeed; my Sister here
Shall be my spy: if she will wrong herself,
And give her right to my wife, I am pleased.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: My dearest life I know, will never fear
Any such will or thought in all my powers:
When I court her then, think I think it is thee:
When I embrace her, hold thee in mine Arms:
Come, let us practice against we see your Father.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Soft Sir, I hope you need not do it yet,
Let me take this time.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Come, you must not touch her.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: No not before my Father?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: No nor now,
Because you are so soon to practise it;
For I must bring them to him presently.
Take her Fortunio; go, hence man and wife,
We will attend you rarely with fixed faces.
Valerio keep your countenance, and conceive
Your Father in your forged sheepishness,
Who thinks thou darest not look upon a Wench,
Nor knowest at which end to begin to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: It is your own too simple lenity,
And doting indulgence shown to him still
That thus hath taught your Son to be no Son,
As you have used him, therefore so you have him:
Durst my Son thus turn rebel to his duty,
Steal up a match unshutting his estate
Without all knowledge of or friend or father;
And to make that good with a worse offence
resolve to run beyond Sea to the wars.
Durst my Son serve me thus? well, I have stayed him,
Though much against my disposition,
And this hour I have set for his repair,
With his young mistress and concealed wife,
And in my house here they shall sojourn both
Till your black angers storm be overblown.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My angers storm? Ah poor Fortunio ,
One gentle word from thee would soon resolve
The storm of my rage to a shower of tears.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: In that vain still? well Marcantonio,
Our old acquaintance and long neighbourhood
Ties my affection to you, and the good
Of your whole house; in kind regard whereof
I have advised you for your credit sake,
And for the tender welfare of your son,
To frown on him a little; if you do not
But at first parley take him to your favour,
I protest utterly to renounce all care
Of you and yours, and all your amities.
They say he is wretched that out of himself
Cannot draw counsel to his proper weal,
But he is thrice wretched that has neither counsel
Within himself, nor apprehension
Of counsel for his own good, from another.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, I will arm myself against this weakness
The best I can; I long to see this Hellene
That hath enchanted my young Paris thus,
And is like to set all our poor Trope on fire.

body.stage: Enter Valerio with a Page. Marc. retyres himselfe.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Here comes my Son; withdraw, take up your stand,
You shall hear odds betwixt your Son and mine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tell him I cannot do it: Shall I be made
A foolish Novice, my Purse set a brooch
By every cheating come you seven? to lend
My Money and be laughed at? tell him plain
I profess Husbandry, and will not play
The Prodigal like him, against my profession.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Here is a Son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: An admirable spark.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Well sir, I will tell him so.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: 'sfoot, let him lead
A better Husbands life, and live not idly,
Spending his time, his coin, and self on Wenches.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Why what is the matter Son ?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Cry mercy Sir; why there comes messengers
From this and that brave Gallant: and such Gallants,
As I protest I saw but through a Grate.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: And what is this Message?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Faith Sir, he is disappointed
Of payments; and disfurnished of means present:
If I would do him the kind office therefore
To trust him but some seven-night with the keeping
Of forty Crowns for me, he deeply swears
As he is a Gentleman, to discharge his trust,
And that I shall eternally endear him
To my wished service, he protests and contests.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Good words Ualerio; but thou art too wise
To be deceived by breath: I will turn thee loose
To the most cunning Cheater of them all.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: 'sfoot, He is not ashamed besides to charge me
With a late Promise: I must yield indeed,
I did (to shift him with some contentment)
Make such a friuall promise.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Aye , well done,
Promises are no Fetters: with that tongue
Thy promise past, unpromise it again,
Wherefore has Man a Tongue, of power to speak ,
But to speak still to his own private purpose?
Beasts utter but one sound; but Men have change
Of speech and Reason, even by Nature given them:
Now to say one thing, and another now,
As best may serve their profitable ends.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: by Our Lady sound instructions to a Son.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Nay Sir, he makes his claim by debt of friendship.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Tush, Friendship is but a Term boy: the fond world
Like to a doting Mother glazes over
Her Children's imperfections with fine terms:
What she calls Friendship and true human kindness,
Is only want of true Experience:
Honesty is but a defect of Wit,
Respect but mere Rusticity and Clownery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Better and better.
Soft, here comes my Son.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Fortunio, keep your countenance: See sir here
The poor young married couple, which you pleased
To send for to your house.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Fortunio welcome,
And in that welcome I employ your wives,
Who I am sure you count your second self.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Sir, your right noble favours do exceed
All power of worthy gratitude by words,
That in your care supply my Fathers place.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Fortunio, I can not choose but love you,
Being Son to him who long time I have loved:
From whose just anger, my house shall protect you,
Till I have made a calm way to your meetings.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: I little thought Sir, that my Fathers love
Would take so ill, so sleight a fault as this.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Call you it sleight? Nay though his spirit take it
In higher manner than for your loved sake,
I would have wished him; yet I make a doubt,
Had my Son done the like, if my affection
Would not have turned to more spleen, than your Fathers:
And yet I qualify him, all I can,
And doubt not but that time and my persuasion,
Will work out your excuse: since youth and love
Were the unresisted organies to seduce you:
But you must give him leave, for Fathers must
Be won by penitence and submission,
And not by force or opposition.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.l: Alas Sir, what advise you me to do?
I know my Father to be highly moved,
And am not able to endure the breath
Of his expressed displeasure, whose hot flames
I think my absence soonest would have quenched.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: True Sir, as fire with oil, or else like them
That quench the sire with pulling down the house,
You shall remain here in my house concealed
Till I have won your Father to conceive
Kinder opinion of your oversight.
Ualerio entertain Fortunio
And his fair wife, and give them conduct in.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What sirrah is that all?
No entertainment to the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Forsooth you are welcome by my Fathers leave.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What no more complement?
Kiss her you sheepshead,
Why when? Go go Sir, call your Sister hither.
Lady, you will pardon our gross bringing up?
We dwell far off from Court you may perceive:
The sight of such a blazing Star as you,
Dazzles my rude Sons wits.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Not so good Sir,
The better husband, the more courtly ever.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Indeed a Courtier makes his lips go far ,
As he doth all things else.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Daughter receive
This Gentlewoman home, and use her kindly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Father bids you kindly welcome Lady,
And therefore you must needs come well to me.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thank you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Go Dame, conduct them in.
Ah errant Sheepshead, hast thou lived thus long,
And darest not look a Woman in the face?
Though I desire especially to see
My Son a Husband, Shall I therefore have him
Turn absolute Cullion? Let us see, kiss thy hand.
Thou kiss thy hand? thou wipest thy mouth by the mass.
Fie on thee Clown; They say the world is grown finer,
But I for my part, never saw Young men
Worse fashioned and brought up than nowadays .
'sfoot, when myself was young, was not I kept
As far from Court as you? I think I was:
And yet my Father on a time invited
The Duchess of his house; I being then
About some five and twenty years of age,
Was thought the only man to entertain her:
I had my Conge; plant myself of one leg,
Draw back the the other with a deep fetched honour:
Then with a Bell regard avaunt mine eye
With boldness on her very visnomie.
Your Dancers all were counterfeits to me:
And for discourse in my fair Mistress presence,
I did not as you barren Gallants do,
Fill my discourses up drinking Tobacco;
But on the present furnished evermore
With tales and practiced speeches; as sometimes
What is it a clock? What stuff is this Petticoat?
What cost the making? What the Fringe and all?
And what she had under her Petticoat?
And such like witty complements: and for need,
I could have written as good Prose and Verse,
As the most beggarly Poet of them all,
Either acrostic, Exordion,
Epithalamious, Satires, Epigrams,
Sonnets in Dozens, or your Quatorzanies,
In any rhyme Masculine, Feminine,
Or Sdrnciolla, or couplets, Blank Verse,
You are but bench-whistlers nowadays to them
That were in our times: well, about your Husbandry,
Go, for I'faith thou art fit for nothing else.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: by Our Lady you have played the Courtier rarely.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: But did you ever see so blank a Fool,
When he should kiss a Wench, as my Son is?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas it is but a little bashfulness,
You let him keep no company, nor allow him
Money to spend at Fence and Dancing schools,
You are too severe i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: And you too supple.
Well Sir, for your sake I have slayed your Son
From flying to the wars: now see you rate him,
To stay him yet from more expenseful courses,
Wherein your lenity will encourage him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let me alone, I thank you for this kindness.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: So, are they gone? Now tell me brave Ualerio
Have I not won the wreath from all your wits,
Brought thee to enjoy the most desired presence
Of thy dear love at home? and with one labour
My brother to enjoy thy sister, where
It had been her undoing to have him seen,
And make thy father crave what he abhors:
To entreat my brother home to enjoy his daughter,
Command thee kiss thy wench, chide for not kissing,
And work all this out of a Machiavelli,
A miserable Politician?
I think the like was never played before!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Indeed I must commend thy wit of force,
And yet I know not whose deserves most praise
Of thine, or my wit: thine for plotting well,
Mine, that durst undertake and carry it
With such true form.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Well, the evening crowns the day,
Persevere to the end, my wit hath put
Blind Fortunne in a string into your hand,
Use it discreetly, keep it from your Father,
Or you may bid all your good days good night.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: Let me alone boy.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Well sir, now to vary
The pleasures of our wits, thou knowest Valerio
Here is the new turned Gentleman's fair wife,
That keeps thy wife and sister company;
With whom the amorous Courtier Doriotto
Is far in love, and of whom her sour husband
Is passing jealous, puts on Eagles eyes
To pry into her carriage. Shall we see.
If he be now from home, and visit her.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: See, see, the prisoner comes.

sp.speaker: Ual.
sp.l: But soft Sir, see
Her jealous Jailer follows at her heels:
Come, we will watch some fitter time to board her,
And in the meantime seek out our mad crew,
My spirit longs to swagger.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Go to youth, walk not too boldly, if the Sergeants meet you;
You may have swaggering work your belly full.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No better Copesmates,
I will go seek them out with this light in my hand,
The slaves grow proud with seeking out of us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A pretty work, I pray what flowers are these?

sp.speaker: Gaze.
sp.l: The Pansy this.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O that is for lovers thoughts.
What is that, a Columbine?

sp.speaker: Gaze.
sp.l: No, that thankless Flower fits not my Garden.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Him? yet it may mine:
This were a pretty present for some friend,
Some gallant Courtier, as for Doriotto,
One that adores you in his soul I know.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Me? why me more than yourself I pray?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O yes, he adores you, and adorns me :
i'faith deal plainly, Do not his kisses relish
Much better than such Peasants as I am?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Whose kisses?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Doriottoes; does he not?
The thing you wot on?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: What thing good Lord?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why Lady, lie with you?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Lie with me?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Aye with you.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: You with me indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay I am told that he lies with you too,
And that he is the only Whoremaster
About the City.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: If he be so only,
It is a good hearing that there are no more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well Mistress well, I will not be abused,
Think not you dance in Nets; for though you do not
Make broad profession of your love to him,
Yet do I understand your darkest language,
Your treads of the toe, your secret jogs and wrings:
Your intercourse of glances: every tittle
Of your close Amorous rites I understand,
They speak as loud to me, as if you said,
My dearest Dariotto, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Iesus what moods are these? did ever Husband
Follow his Wife with Jealousy so unjust?
That once I loved you, you yourself will swear.
And if I did, where did you lose my Love?
Indeed this strange and undeserved usage,
Hath power to shake a heart were never so settled:
But I protest all your unkindness, never
Had strength to make me wrong you, but in thought.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No, not with Doriotto?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: No by heaven.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No Letters past, nor no designs for meeting?

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: No by my hope of heaven.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, no time past,
Go go; go in and sow.

sp.speaker: Gaz.
sp.l: Well, be it so.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Suspicion is (they say) the first degree
Of deepest wisdom: and however others
Inveigh against this mood of Jealousy,
For my part I suppose it the best curb,
To check the ranging appetites that reign
In this weak sex: my neighbours point at me
For this my jealousy; but should I do
As most of them do; let my wife fly out
To feasts and revels, and invite home Gallants,
Play Menelaus, give them time and place,
While I sit like a well-taught waiting woman,
Turning her eyes upon some work or picture,
Reading a Book, or take a feigned nap,
While her kind Lady takes one to her lap?
No, let me still be pointed at, and thought
A jealous Ass, and not a wittolly Knave.
I have a show of Courtiers haunt my house,
In show my friends, and for my profit too:
But I perceive them, and will mock their aims,
With looking to their mark, I warrant them:
I am content to ride abroad with them,
To revel, dice, and fit their other sports;
But by their leaves I will have a vigilant eye
To the main chance still. See my brave Comrades.

body.stage: Enter Dariotto, Claudio and Valerio: Valerio putting up his Sword.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Well, wag, well, wilt thou still deceive thy father,
And being so simple a poor soul before him,
Turn swaggerer in all companies besides?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Hadst thou been rested, all would have come forth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Soft, sir, there lies the point; I do not doubt,
But to have my penny worths of these Rascals one day:
I will smoke the buzzing Hornets from their nests,
Or else I will make their leather jerkins stay.
The whoreson hungry Horseflies; Foot, a man
Cannot so soon, for want of Almanacs,
Forget his day but three or four bare months,
But strait he fees a sort of Corporals,
To lie in Ambuscado to surprise him.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Well, thou hadst happy fortune to escape them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But they thought theirs was happier to scape me.
I walking in the place, where men's law suites
Are heard and pleaded, not so much as dreaming
Of any such encounter, steps me forth
Their valiant foreman, with the word, I rest you.
I made no more ado, but laid these paws
Close on his shoulders, tumbling him to earth;
And there sate he on his posteriors,
Like a Baboon; and turning me about,
I straight espied the whole troop issuing on me.
I stepped me back, and drawing my old friend here,
Made to the midst of them, and all unable
To endure the shock, all rudely fell in rout,
And down the stairs they ran with such a fury,
As meeting with a troop of Lawyers there,
Manned by their Clients: some with ten, some with twenty,
Some five, some three; he that had least, had one:
Upon the stairs they bore them down afore them:
But such a rattling then was there amongst them
Of ravished Declarations, Replications,
Rejoinders and Petitions; all their books
And writings torn and trod on, and some lost,
That the poor Lawyers coming to the Bar,
Could say naught to the matter, but instead,
Were fain to rail and talk besides their books
Without all order.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Faith, that same vain of railing became
Now most applausive; your best Poet, is
He that rails grossest.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: True, and your best fool
Is your broad railing fool.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And why not, sir?
For by the gods, to tell the naked truth,
What objects see men in this world, but such
As would yield matter to a railing humour:
When he that last year carried after one
An empty Buckram bag, now fills a Coach,
And crowds the Senate with such troops of Clients,
And servile followers, as would put a mad spleen
Into a Pigeon.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Come, pray leave these cross capers,
Let us make some better use of precious time.
See, here is Cornelio: come, Lad, shall we to dice?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Anything I.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Well said, how does thy wife?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In health, God save her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But where is she, man?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Abroad about her business.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, not at home?
Foot, my masters, take her to the Court,
And this rare Lad her husband: and dost hear?
Play me no more the miserable Farmer,
But be advised by friends, sell all in the country,
Be a flat Courtier, follow some great man,
Or bring thy wife there, and she will make thee great.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What, to the Court? then take me for a Gull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, never shun it to be called a Gull:
For I see all the world is but a Gull:
One man Gull to another in all kinds:
A Merchant to a Courtier is a Gull:
A Client to a Lawyer is a Gull:
A married man to a Bachelor, a Gull:
A Bachelor to a Cuckold is a Gull:
All to a Poet, or a Poet to himself.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Hark Dariotto, shall we gull this Guller?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: He gulls his father, man, we cannot gull him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Let me alone. Of all men's wits alive,
I most admire Valerioe, that hath stolen,
By his mere industry, and that by spurts,
Such qualities, as no wit else can match,
With plodding at perfection every hour;
Which, if his father knew each gift he has,
Were like enough to make him give all from him:
I mean besides his dicing and his wenching,
He has stolen languages, the Italian, Spanish,
And some spice of the French, besides his dancing,
Singing, playing on choice Instruments:
These has he got, almost against the hair.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: But hast thou stolen all these, Valerio?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Toys, toys, a pox; and yet they be such toys,
As every Gentleman would not be without.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Vain glory makes ye judge on light i'faith.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Before heaven I was much deceived in him:
But he is the man indeed that hides his gifts,
And sets them not to sale in every presence.
I would have sworn, his soul were far from music;
And that all his choice music was to hear
His fat beasts bellow.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sir, your ignorance
Shall eftsoon be confuted. Prithee Val,
Take thy Theorbo for my sake a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By heaven, this month I touched not a Theorbo.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Touched a Theorbo? mark the very word,
Sirrah, go fetch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If you will have it, I must needs confess,
I am no husband of my qualities.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: See what a Caper there was!

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: See again.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The best that ever; and how it becomes him!

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: O that his father saw these qualities!

body.stage: Enter a Page with an Instrument.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Nay, that is the very wonder of his wit,
To carry all without his fathers knowledge.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Why, we might tell him now.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No but we could not,
Although we think we could: his wit doth charm us .
Come sweet Val, touch and sing.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Foot, will you hear
The worst voice in Italy?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O God, sir.
Courtiers, how like you this?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Believe it excellent.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Is it not natural?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: If my father heard me,
Foot, he would renounce me for his natural son.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: By heaven Valerio, and I were thy father,
And loved good qualities as I do my life,
I would disinherit thee: for I never heard
Dog howl with worse grace.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Go to, Seignior Courtier,
You deal not courtly now to be so plain,
Nor nobly, to discourage a young Gentleman,
In virtuous qualities, that has but stolen them .

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Call you this touching a Theorbo?

sp.speaker: Omn
sp.l: ha, ha, ha.

body.stage: Exeunt all but Val. and Rin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How now, what is here?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: 'swounds, a plot laid to gull thee.
Could thy wit think the voice was worth the hearing?
This was the Courtiers and the Cuckolds project.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And is it even so? it is very well, mast Courtier, and; Dan Cornuto, I will cry quit with both: And first, I will cast a jar betwixt them both, with firing the poor cuckolds jealousy. I have a tale will make him mad,
And turn his wife divorced loose amongst us.
But first let us home, and entertain my wife.
O father, pardon, I was borne to gull thee.

body.stage: Enter Fortunio, Bellanora, Gratiana, Gostanzo following closely.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: How happy am I, that by this sweet means
I gain access to your most loved sight,
And there withal to utter my full love,
Which but for vent would burn my entrails up!

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: By the mass they talk too softly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Little thinks
The austere mind my thrifty father bears,
That I am vowed to you, and so am bound
From him: who for more riches he would force
On my dishking fancy.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: It is no fault,
With just deeds to defraud an injury.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: My daughter is persuading him to yield
In dutiful submission to his father.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do I not dream? do I behold this sight
With waking eyes? or from the Ivory gate
Hath Morpheus sent a vision to delude me?
Is it possible that I a mortal man,
Should shrine within mine arms so bright a Goddess,
The fair Gratiana, beauties little world!

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My dearest Mine of Gold,
All this that thy white arms enfold,
Account it as thine own free-hold.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: God is my dear soul, what sudden change is here!
I smell how this gear will fall out i'faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Fortunio, sister; come, let us to the garden.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Sits the wind there i'faith? see what example
Will work upon the dullest appetite.
My son last day so bashful, that he durst not
Look on a wench, now courts her; and by Our Lady,
Will make his friend Fortunio wear his head
Of the right modern fashion. What Rinaldo.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I fear I interrupt your privacy.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Welcome, Rinaldo, would it had been your hap
To come a little sooner, that you might
Have seen a handsome sight: but let that pass,
The short is, that your sister Gratiana
Shall stay no longer here.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: No longer, sir?
Repent you then so soon your favour to her,
And to my brother?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Not so, good Rinaldo;
But to prevent a mischief that I see
Hangs over your abused brothers head.
In brief, my son has learned but too much courtship.
It was my chance even now to cast mine eye
Into a place whereto your sister entered:
My metamorphosed son: I must conceal
What I saw there: but to be plain, I saw
More than I would see: I had thought to make
My house a kind receipt for your kind brother;
But I would be loath his wife should find more kindness,
Than she had cause to like of.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: What is the matter?
Perhaps a little complement or so.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Well, sir, such complement perhaps may cost
Married Fortunio the setting on:
Nor can I keep my knowledge; He that lately
Before my face I could not get to look
Upon your sister; by this light, now kissed her,
Embraced and courted with as good a grace,
As any Courtier could: and I can tell you
(Not to disgrace her) I perceived the Dame
Was as far forward as himself by the , mass.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: You should have schooled him for it.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: No, I will not see it:
For shame once found, is lost; I will have him think
That my opinion of him is the same
That it was ever; it will be a mean,
To bridle this fresh humour bred in him.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Let me then school him; foot, I will rattle him up.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: No, no, Rinaldo, the only remedy,
Is to remove the cause; carry the object
From his late tempted eyes.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Alas, sir, whither?
You know, my father is incensed so much,
He will not receive her.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Place her with some friend
But for a time, till I reclaim your father:
Mean time your brother shall remain with me.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: The care is the less then, he has still his longing,
To be with this Gulls daughter.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: What resolve you?
I am resolved she lodges here no more:
My friends son shall not be abused by mine.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I will tell you what a sudden toy comes in my head; what think you if I brought her home to my fathers house?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Aye marry, sir;
Would he receive her?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Nay, you hear not all:
I mean, with use of some device or other.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: As how, Rinaldo?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Marry sir, to say,
She is your sons wife, married past your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: I doubt, last day he saw her, and will know her to be Fortunioes wife.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Nay, as for that
I will pretend she was even then your sons wife,
But feigned by me to be Fortunioes,
Only to try how he would take the matter.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Before heaven it were pretty.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Would it not do well?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Exceeding well in sadness.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Nay, good sir,
Tell me unfeignedly, do ye like it indeed.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: The best that ere I heard.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: And do you think
He will swallow down the Gudgeon?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: On my life
It were a gross gob would not down with him,
An honest knight, but simple, not acquainted
With the fine slights and policies of the world,
As I myself am.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I will go fetch her strait:
And this jest thrive, it will make us princely sports
But you must keep our counsel, second all,
Which to make likely, you must needs sometimes
Give your son leave (as if you knew it not)
To steal and see her at my fathers house.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Aye , but see you then that you keep good guard
Over his forward new begun affections:
For by the Lord, he will teach your brother else,
To sing the Cuckoos note: spirit will break out,
Though never so suppressed and pinioned.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Especially your sons: what would he be,
If you should not restrain him by good counsel?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: I will have an eye on him, I warrant thee.
I will in and warn the Gentlewoman to make ready.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Well, sir, and I will not be long after you.
Heaven, heaven, I see these Politicians
(Out of blind Fortunes hands) are our most fools.
It is she that gives the lustre to their wits,
Still plodding at traditional devices:
But take them out of them to present actions,
A man may grope and tickle them like a Trout,
And take them from their close dear holes, as fat
As a Physician; and as giddy-headed,
As if be miracle heaven had taken from them,
Even that which commonly belongs to fools.
Well, now let us note what black ball of debate,
Valerios wit hath cast betwixt Cornelio,
And the enamoured Courtier; I believe
His wife and he will part: his jealousy
Hath ever watched occasion of divorce,
And now Valerioes villainy will present it,
See, here comes the twin courtier his companion.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Rinaldo, well encountered.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Why? what news?

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Most sudden and infortunate, Rinaldo:
Cornelio is incensed so against his wife,
That no man can procure her quiet with him.
I have assayed him, and made Marc Antonio,
With all his gentle Rhetoric second me,
Yet all I fear me will be cast away.
See, see, they come: join thy wit, good Rinaldo,
And help to pacify his yellow fury.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: With all my heart, I consecrate my wit
To the wished comfort of distressed Ladies.

body.stage: Enter Cornelio, Marc Ant. Valerio, Page.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Will any man assure me of her good behaviour?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who can assure a jealous spirit? you may be afraid of the shadow of your ears,and imagine them to be horns: if you will assure yourself, appoint keepers to watch her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And who shall watch the keepers?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To be sure of that, be you her keeper.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well said, and share the horns yourself:
For that is the keepers fee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But say I am gone out of town, and must trust others; how shall I know if those I trust be trusty to me?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Marry, sir, by a singular instinct,given naturally to all you married men, that if your wives play legerdeheele, though you be a hundred miles off, yet you shall be sure instantly to find it in your foreheads.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Sound doctrine I warrant you: I am resolved i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Then give me leave to speak, sir, that hath all this while been silent: I have heard you with extreme patience, now therefore prick up your ears, and vouchsafe me audience.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Good boy, a mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Pray what are you, sir?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: I am here, for default of better, of counsel with the fair Gazetta, and though herself had been best able to defend herself, if she had been here, and would have pleased to put forth the Buckler, which Nature hath given all women, I mean her tongue.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Excellent good boy.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Yet since she either vouchsafes it not, or thinks her innocence a sufficient shield against your jealous accusations, I will presume to undertake the defence of that absent and honourable Lady, whose sworn Knight I am; and in her of all that name (for Lady is grown a common name to their whole sex) which sex I have ever loved from my youth, and shall never cease to love, till I want wit to admire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: An excellent spoken boy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Give ear, Cornelio, here is a young Mercurio sent to persuade thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, sir, let him say on.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: It is a heavy case, to see how this light sex is tubled and tossed from post to pillar,under the unsavoury breath of every humorous Peasant: Gazetta, you said, is unchaste, disloyal, and I wot not what; Alas, is it her fault? is she not a woman? did she not suck it (as others of her sex do) from her mothers breast? and will you condemn that, as her fault, which is her Nature? Alas, sir, you must consider, a woman is an unfinished Creature, delivered hastily to the world, before Nature had set to that Scale which should have made them perfect. Faults they have (no doubt) but are we free? Turn your eye into yourself (good Seignior Cornelio) and weigh your own imperfections with hers: If she be wanton abroad, are not you wanting at home? if she be amorous, are not you jealous? If she be high set, are not you taken down ? If she be a Courtesan, are not you a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Out you rogue.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: On with thy speech boy.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: You do not well, Cornelio, to discourage the bashful youth.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Forth, boy, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: But if our own imperfections will not teach us to bear with theirs; yet let their virtues persuade us: let us endure their bad qualities for their good; allow the prickle for the Rose; the brack for the Velvet; the paring for the cheese, and so forth: if you say they range abroad, consider it is nothing but to avoid idleness at home: their nature is still to be doing: keep them adoing at home; let them practise one good quality or other, either sowing, singing, playing, chiding, dancing or so, and these will put such idle toys out of their heads into yours: but if you cannot find them variety of business within doors, yet at least imitate the ancient wise Citizens of this City, who used carefully to provide their wives gardens near the town, to plant, to graft in, as occasion served, only to keep them from idleness.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Everlasting good boy.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I perceive your knavery, sir, and will yet have patience.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Forth, my brave Curio.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: As to her unquietness (which some have rudely termed shrewishness) though the fault be in her, yet the cause is in you. What so calm as the sea of it own nature? Art was never able to equal it: your dicing tables, nor your bowling alleys are not comparable to it; yet if a blast of wind do but cross it, not so turbulent and violent an element in the world: So (nature in lieu of women's scarcity of wit, having endued them with a large portion of will) if they may (without impeach) enjoy their wills, no quieter creatures under heaven: but if the breath of their husbands mouths once cross their wills, nothing more tempestuous. Why then, sir, should you husbands cross your wives wills thus, considering the law allows them no wills at all at their deaths, because it intended they should have their wills while they lived?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Answer him but that, Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: All shall not serve her turn, I am thinking of other matters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou hast half won him, Wag; ply him yet a little further.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Now (sit) for these Cuckooish songs of yours, of Cuckolds, horns, grafting, and such like; what are they, but mere imaginary toys, bred out of your own heads, as your own, and so by tradition delivered from man to man, like Scarecrows, to terrify fools from this earthly paradise of wedlock, coined at first by some spent Poets, superannuated Bachelors, or some that were scarce men of their hands; who, like the Fox, having lost his tail, would persuade others to lose theirs for company? Again , for your Cuckold, what is it but a mere fiction? show me any such creature in nature; if there be, I could never see it, neither could I ever find any sensible difference betwixt a Cuckold and a Christen creature. To conclude, let Poets coin, or fools credit what they list; for mine own part, I am clear of this opinion, that your Cuckold is a mere Chimera, and that there are no Cuckolds in the world, but those that have wives: and so I will leave them.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: It is excellent good, sir; I do take you, sir, do you see? to be, as it were bastard to the saucy Courtier, that would have me father more of your fraternity, do you see? and so are instructed (as we hear) to second that villain with your tongue, which he has acted with his Tenure piece, do you see?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: No such matter, on my credit, sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Well, sir, be as be may, I scorn to set my head against yours, do you see? when in the mean time I will firk your father, whether you see or no.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Gods my life, Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Have at your father i'faith, boy, if he can find him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See, he comes here, he has missed him.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: How now, my hearts, what, not a wench amongst you?
It is a sign you are not in the grace of wenches,
That they will let you be thus long alone.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, Dariotto, glory not too much,
That for thy brisk attire and lips perfumed,
Thou playest the Stallion ever where thou comest;
And like the husband of the flock, runnest through
The whole town heard, and no man's bed secure:
No woman's honour unattempted by thee.
Think not to be thus fortunate forever:
But in thy amorous conquests at the last
Some wound will slice your mazer: Mars himself
Fell into Vulcan's snare, and so may you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Alas, alas, faith I have but the name:
I love to court and win; and the consent,
Without the act obtained, is all I seek.
I love the victory that draws no blood.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: O, it is a high desert in any man
To be a secret Lecher; I know some,
That (like thyself) are true in nothing else.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And, methinks , it is nothing, if not told;
At least the joy is never full before.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, Dariotto, thou hadst as good confess,
The Sun shines broad upon your practices.
Vulcan will wake and intercept you one day.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Why, the more jealous knave and coxcomb he.
What, shall the shaking of his bed a little
Put him in motion? It becomes him not;
Let him be dulled and stalled, and then be quiet.
The way to draw my custom to his house,
Is to be mad and jealous; it is the sauce
That whets my appetite.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Or any man's:
They that are jealous, use it still of purpose
To draw you to their houses.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Aye , by heaven,
I am of that opinion. Who would steal
Out of a common Orchard? Let me gain
My love with labour, and enjoy it with fear,
Or I am gong.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: What, Dariotto here?
Foot,darest thou come near Cornelioes house?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Why? is the Bull run mad? what ails he, trow?

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: I know not what he ails; but I would wish you
To keep out of the reach of his sharpe horns:
For by this hand he will gore you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: And why me,
More than thyself , or these two other whelps?
You all have basted him as well as I,
I wonder what is the cause.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Nay, that he knows,
And swears withal, that wheresoever he meets you,
He will mark you for a marker of men's wives.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pray heaven he be not jealous by some tales
That have been told him lately: did you never
Attempt his wife? hath no Loves Harbinger,
No looks, no letters past twixt you and her?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: For look I cannot answer; I bestow them
At large, and carelessly, much like the Sun:
If any be so foolish to apply them
To any private fancy of their own,
(As many do) it is not my fault, thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, Dariotto, this set face of thine
(If thou be guilty of offence to him)
Comes out of very want of wit and feeling
What danger haunts thee: for Cornelio
Is a tall man, I tell you; and it were best
You shunned his sight awhile, till we might get
His patience, or his pardon: for past doubt
Thou diest if he but see thee.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Foot, he comes.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Is this the Cockatrice that kills with fight?
How dost thou boy? ha?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: What, lingering still
About this paltry town? hadst thou been ruled
By my advice, thou hadst by this time been
A gallant Courtier, and at least a Knight:
I would have got thee dubbed by this time certain.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And why then did you not yourself that honour?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Tush, it is more honour still to make a Knight,
Than it is to be a Knight: to make a Cuckold,
Than it is to be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You are a villain.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: God shield man: villain?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Aye , I will prove thee one.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: What, wilt thou prove a villain?
By this light thou deceivest me then.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, sir, thus I prove it.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Hold, hold, raise the streets.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Hold, Darioto, hold.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, art thou hurt?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: A scratch, a scratch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Go sirrah, fetch a Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You will set a badge on the jealous fools head, sir;
Now set a Coxcomb on your own.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What is the cause of these wars, Darioto?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Foot, I know not.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, sir, know and spare not; I will presently be divorced, and then take her amongst ye.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Divorced, nay good Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: By this sword I will, the world shall not dissuade me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why this has been your fault now Darioto,
You youths have fashions when you have obtained:
A Ladies favour, straight your hat must wear it,
Like a Jackdaw that when he lights upon
A dainty morsel kaas and makes his brags,
And then some kite doth scoop it from him straight,
Where if he fed without his dawish noise,
He might fare better, and have less disturbance:
Forbear it in this case: and when you prove,
Victorious over fair Gazettas Forte,
Do not for pity sound your trump for joy,
But keep your valour close, and it is your honour.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: God save you Seignior Darioto.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: I know you not Sir, your name I pray?

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: My name is Pock Sir; a practitioner in Surgery,

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Pock the Surgeon, you are welcome Sir, I know a Doctor of your name master Pock.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: My name has made many Doctors Sir.

sp.speaker: Rinal.
sp.l: Indeed it is a worshipful name.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Marry is it, and of an ancient descent.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: Faith Sir I could fetch my pedigree far, if I were so disposed.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Out of France at least.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: And if I stood on my arms as others do,

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: No do not Pock, let other stand a their arms, and thou a thy legs as long as thou canst.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: Though I live by my bare practise, yet I could show good cards for my Gentility.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tush thou canst not shake off thy gentry Pock, it is bred in the bone; but to the main Pock, what thinkest thou of this gentleman's wound, Pock canst thou cure it Pock.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.p: The incision is not deep, nor the Orifice exorbitant, the Pericranion is not dislocated, I warrant his life for forty crowns, without perishing of any joint.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Faith Pock, it is a joint I would be loath to lose, for the best joint of Mutton in Italy.

sp.speaker: Rin.
sp.l: Would such a scratch as this hazards a man's head?

sp.speaker: Foc.
sp.p: Aye by Our Lady Sir, I have known some have lost their heads for a less matter I can tell you, therefore sir you must keep good diet: if you please to come home to my house till you be perfectly cured, I shall have the more care on you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That is your only course to have it well quickly.

sp.speaker: Poc.
sp.l: By what time would he have it well sir.

sp.speaker: Dari.
sp.l: A very necessary question, canst thou limit the time.

sp.speaker: Pock.
sp.p: O sir, cures are like causes in law, which may be lengthened or shortened at the discretion of the Lawyer, he can either keep it greene with replications or rejoinders, or sometimes skin it fair of the outside for fashion sake, but so he may be sure it will break out again by a writ of error, and then has he his suite new to begin, but I will covenant with you, that by such a time I will make your head as sound as a Bell, I will bring it to suppuration and after I will make it coagulate and grow to a perfect Cicatrice, and all within these ten days, so you keep a good diet.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.p: Well come Pock, we will talk farther on it within, it draws near dinner time;what is o'clock boy?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: By your clock sir it should be almost one, for your head rung noon some half hour ago.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Is it true sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Away let him alone, though he came in at the window he sets the gates of your honour open I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: Come in Pock, come, apply; and for this deed
I will give the Knave a wound shall never bleed:
So sir I think this knock rings loud acquittance,
For my ridiculous.

body.stage: Exeunt all but Rinal. and Valer.

sp.speaker: Ryn.
sp.l: Well sir to turn our heads to salve your licence,
Since you have used the matter so unwisely,
That now your father has discerned your humour,
In your too careless usage in his house,
Your wife must come from his house to Antonios,
And he, to entertain her must be told
She is not wife to his son, but to you:
Which news will make his simple wit triumph
Over your father; and your father thinking
He still is gulled, will still account him simple:
Come sir, prepare your villainous wit to fain
A kind submission to your fathers fury,
And we shall see what hearty policy,
He will discover, in his fained Anger,
To blind Antonios eyes, and make him think,
He thinks her heartily to be your wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O I will gull him rarely with my wench,
Low kneeling at my heels before his fury,
And injury shall be salved with injury.

sp.speaker: Marc-Ant.
sp.l: You see how too much wisdom evermore,
Overshoots the truth: you were so forwards still,
To tax my ignorance, my greene experience
In these gray hairs, for giving such advantage,
To my sons spirit, that he durst undertake
A secret match, so far short of his worth:
Your son so seasoned with obedience,
Even from his youth, that all his actions relish
Nothing but duty, and your angers fear,
What shall I say to you, if it fall out
That this most precious son of yours, has played
A part as bad as this, and as rebellious:
Nay more has grossly gulled your wit withal.
What if my son has undergone the blame
That appertained to yours? and that this wench
With which my son is charged, may call you father:
Shall I then say you want experience?
You are greene, you are credulous; easy to be blinded.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, good Marc-Antonio,
When it comes to that; laugh at me, call me fool, proclaim me so,
Let all the world take knowledge I am an Ass.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O the good God of Gods,
How blind is Pride? what Eagles we are still,
In matters that belong to other men?
What Beetles in our own? I tell you Knight,
It is confessed to be as I have told you;
And Gratiana, is by young Rinaldo,
And your white son, brought to me as his wife:
How think you now Sir?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Even just as before,
And have more cause to think honest Credulity,
Is a true Lodestone to draw on Decrepity:
You have a heart too open to embrace,
All that your ear receives: alas good man,
All this is but a plot for entertainment
Within your house, for your poor sons young wife
My house without huge danger cannot hold:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is it possible, what danger Sir I pray?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: I will tell you Sir, it was time to take her thence:
My son that last day you saw could not frame,
His looks to entertain her, now by Our Lady
Is groan a Courtier: for myself unseen,
Saw when he courted her, embraced and kissed her,
And I can tell you left not much undone,
That was the proper office of your son.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What world is this?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: I told this to Rinaldo,
Advising him to fetch her from my house,
And his young wit not knowing where to lodge her
Unless with you: and saw that could not be,
Without some wile: I presently suggested
This quaint devise, to say she was my sons:
And all this plot, good Marc-Antonio,
Flowed from this fount, only to blind our eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out of how sweet a dream have you awaked me?
By heaven, I durst have laid my part in heaven
All had been true; it was so lively handled,
And drawn with such a seeming face of truth:
Your son had cast a perfect vail of grief
Over his face, for his so rash offence,
To seal his love with act of marriage,
Before his father had subscribed his choice:
My son (my circumstance lessening the fact)
Entreating me to break the matter to you,
And joining my effectual persuasions,
With your sons penitent submission,
Appease your fury; I at first assented,
And now expect their coming to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: It was well it was well, seem to believe it still,
Let Art end what Credulity began,
When they come, suite your words and looks to theirs,
Second my sad Sons fained submission,
And see in all points how my brain will answer,
His disguised grief; with a set countenance
Of rage and choler; now observe and learn
To school your son by me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: On with your mask; here come the other maskers sir,

sp.speaker: Rinal.
sp.l: Come on I say,
Your Father with submission will be calmed; come on, down on your knees:

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Villain durst thou
Presume to gull thy Father? dost thou not
Tremble to see my bent and cloudy brows
Ready to thunder on thy graceless head,
And with the bolt of my displeasure cut
The thread of all my living from thy life,
For taking thus a beggar to thy wife?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Father, if that part I have in your blood,
If tears, which so abundantly distill
Out of my inward eyes: and for a need,
Can drown these outward (lend me thy hand-kercher)
And being indeed as many drops of blood,
Issuing from the Creator of my heart,
Be able to beget so much compassion,
Not on my life, but on this lovely Dame,
Whom I hold dearer?

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Out upon thee villain.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Nay good Gostanzo, think you are a Father.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: I will not hear a word; out, out upon thee:
Wed without my advise, my love, my knowledge,
Aye , and a beggar too, a trull, a blowze?

sp.speaker: Rinal.
sp.l: You thought not so last day, when you offered her
A twelve months board for one nights lodging with her.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Go to, no more of that, peace good Rinaldo,
It is a fault that only she and you know.

sp.speaker: Rein.
sp.l: Well sir, go on I pray.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Have I fond wretch,
